Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) for FY 2013 in China
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Christina Frederick of The University of Texas at Austin to conduct a research project in the Mathematical and Physical Sciences area during the summer of 2013 at the Institute of Computational Mathematics and Scientific and Engineering Computing of Chinese Academy of Sciences in Beijing, China. The project title is "Discovering Fine Scale Features in Effective Systems Using Heterogeneous Multiscale Methods." The host scientist is Dr. Pingbing Ming.

A challenging task in the design of models for the complex processes that arise in science and engineering is capturing features at a wide range of spatial or temporal scales with numerical methods that are computationally inexpensive. The recently developed Heterogeneous Multiscale Methods (HMM) provide a framework for the design of such numerical methods that enhance current models by incorporating local microscale calculations. This project reverses the process and analyzes the use of HMM in recovering microscale features of a system from given coarse scale data.

Broader impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce. Furthermore, this proposed research can be applied to inverse problems in a wide range of disciplines including geophysics, medical imaging, and materials science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project we proposed new mathematical techniques to efficiently identify small-scale patterns in physical data. A motivating application is seismic imaging, in which large volumes of data are analyzed to determine microstructural properties of the earth's subsurface.  The theoretical aspect of this project is important because we are applying multiscale techniques and incorporating known features in the forward model. In terms of scientific computation, this project addresses the growing need for higher fidelity models with larger time and spatial scales.

The major goal of the project was to further develop numerical algorithms to solve these problems using the Heterogeneous Multiscale Method (HMM). Specifically, we aimed to 1) create synthetic seismic data and perform numerical case studies 2) understand the role of HMM micro scale solver in the inversion process 3) identify theoretical questions that relate multiscale modeling and inversion. MATLAB code was produced to incorporate different microscale features, such as thickness and angle of subsurface layers. Numerical results from inversion of these models are currently being incorporated into a manuscript.

The summer fellowship also resulted in professional and cultural gains. In addition to participating in courses on Chinese language, history, and culture, the PI began collaboration with Pingbing Ming at LSEC, Institute of Computational Mathematics and Scientific/Engineering Computing, AMSS, Chinese Academy of Sciences in Beijing, China. The PI attended the Shanghai PRIMA International Mathematics conference in July 2013 and presented a poster detailing the results at the 4th US/China Young Scientists Forum in Beijing, China in August 2013.
